item.title: India, Irate Over Arrest of Consular Employee, Retaliates Against U.S. Diplomats
item.description: Diplomats in India are facing a revocation of privileges and tax investigations prompted by the arrest of an Indian representative in New York.
item.dc:creator: By GARDINER HARRIS

item.title: The Lede: Freed Pussy Riot Activists Stand Firm and Shift Focus
item.description: The activists, who held a news conference in Moscow, stood by their opposition to President Vladimir K. Putin of Russia, and said they were starting a human rights organization.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: By CHRISTINE HAUSER

item.title: Big Spanish Labor Union Facing an Investigation on Misuse of Funding
item.description: The regional government of Andalusia contends $2.46 million in public money was spent illegally to pay for events and gifts to officials.
item.dc:creator: By RAPHAEL MINDER
item.media:description: A rally last month against budget cuts in Spain.

item.title: The Lede: Last Words From a Beirut Bombing Victim
item.description: The blast struck the heart of Beirut’s business district, killing six people, one of them a senior Lebanese politician who had been critical of Hezbollah and the Syrian government.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By CHRISTINE HAUSER

item.title: World Brief | Middle East: Syrian Security Forces Kill Dozens of Rebels in Ambush
item.description: The Syrian security forces struck near the town of Maaloula, north of Damascus, Syrian rebels and government television said.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By ANNE BARNARD

item.title: Deadly Bomb Attack Hits Restaurant in Somali Capital
item.description: There was no immediate claim of responsibility, but local officials say they suspect the Shabab, an Islamist militant group based in Somalia with links to Al Qaeda.
item.dc:creator: By DAN BILEFSKY

item.title: Bomb in Beirut Kills Politician, a Critic of Syria and Hezbollah
item.description: The blast was the first to hit Beirut’s downtown since 2005, and among the six dead was Mohamad B. Chatah, a former Lebanese finance minister and ambassador to the U.S.
item.dc:creator: By ANNE BARNARD and DAN BILEFSKY
item.media:description: Mohamad B. Chatah, a former Lebanese government minister and ambassador to the United States, was said to be among the victims and possibly the target.

item.title: India Ink: Image of the Day: December 27
item.description: Laborers keeping themselves warm on a cold day in New Delhi.
item.dc:creator: By THE NEW YORK TIMES
item.media:description: Laborers keeping themselves warm near a small bonfire at an under construction building in New Delhi. Temperatures dipped in several parts of North India on Friday.

item.title: 3 Coalition Soldiers Killed in Attack on Convoy in Kabul
item.description: At least six civilians were also wounded in the car bomb explosion, which underlined the continuing threat to foreign troops in Afghanistan.
item.dc:creator: By AZAM AHMED

item.title: India Ink: A Conversation With: Aam Aadmi Party Leader Arvind Kejriwal
item.description: The day before he was to embark on his new career as Delhi’s chief minister, Mr. Kejriwal talked about what lies ahead for him and his party.
item.dc:creator: By BETWA SHARMA
item.media:description: Arvind Kejriwal, Delhi's next chief minister, at a public meeting in New Delhi, on Sunday.

item.title: India Ink: Indian Deaths Underscore Risks in U.N. Peacekeeping Missions
item.description: The conflict in South Sudan has expanded to attacks on civilians, straining the United Nations troops’ ability to protect the populace.
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.dc:creator: By BETWA SHARMA
item.media:description: Remains of two UN soldiers from the Indian battalion, killed in an attack at Akobo in Jonglei state, being transported to Juba, South Sudan, on Dec. 20.

item.title: Prosecutor Overseeing Turkish Graft Inquiry Is Removed From Case
item.description: The removal of the prosecutor, Muammer Akkas, is a new sign of a profound power struggle over Turkey’s judiciary and police forces.
item.dc:creator: By TIM ARANGO

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: With Flowers, Ai Weiwei Protests His Loss of Freedom
item.description: Banned from leaving China for nearly three years now, the artist and dissident Ai Weiwei is protesting — by placing fresh flowers in the basket of a bicycle outside his studio in Beijing every day, he says.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: By DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW

item.title: Deal to Move Okinawa Base Wins Approval
item.description: A long-simmering dispute between the United States and Japan over the fate of a Marine base on Okinawa seemed to have been resolved on Friday.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: By HIROKO TABUCHI and THOM SHANKER
item.media:description: The Marine Corps’ Futenma Air Station in Okinawa. The approximately 18,000 Marines now stationed on Okinawa will drop to about 10,000 once the new base is completed over the next decade.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Homeowner’s ‘Cannons’ Warn Demolition Teams: No Closer
item.description: Determined to protect his home from being razed, a man in Henan Province has stationed six “cannons” outside it. They apparently cannot be fired, but they are drawing attention.
item.dc:creator: By DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW

item.title: Deal to Move Okinawa Base Wins Approval
item.description: A long-simmering dispute between the United States and Japan over the fate of a Marine base on Okinawa seemed to have been resolved on Friday.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: By HIROKO TABUCHI and THOM SHANKER

item.title: Russian Inquiry Finds No Radiation Link to Arafat’s Death
item.description: Teams of scientists from France, Switzerland and Russia had been asked to determine whether polonium played a role in the 2004 death of Yasir Arafat, the former Palestinian leader.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Egypt Broadens New Crackdown on Brotherhood
item.description: With dozens of arrests and the seizure of land, stocks and vehicles, Egypt’s new rulers signaled that they had opened a wide-ranging war on every facet of the Muslim Brotherhood’s activities.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By KAREEM FAHIM and MAYY EL SHEIKH
item.media:description: Egypt’s government accuses the Muslim Brotherhood of orchestrating a fatal attack on Tuesday.

item.title: Frederick Fox, Milliner to Royals, Dies at 82
item.description: Beginning in 1970, Mr. Fox designed more than 350 hats for Queen Elizabeth. His trademark skill, admirers said, was to mix whimsy and propriety.
item.category: Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain
item.dc:creator: By PAUL VITELLO
item.media:description: Frederick Fox, shown in 1993, with a hat made for Queen Elizabeth II.

item.title: Johannesburg Journal: South Africans Band Together, Finding a New Enemy in Highway Tolls
item.description: A new road toll system has prompted a battle of words between protesters and the South African government.
item.dc:creator: By JOHN ELIGON
item.media:description: Protesters rallied this month against a toll system built by the South African government.

item.title: News Analysis: With Shrine Visit, Leader Asserts Japan’s Track From Pacifism
item.description: A visit to the Yasukuni Shrine highlighted Prime Minister Shinzo Abe’s willingness to take on big political risks as he tries to build a more powerful Japan.
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.dc:creator: By HIROKO TABUCHI
item.media:description: Prime Minister Shinzo Abe’s visit to the Yasukuni Shrine in Tokyo angered China and South Korea. Relations with both nations are already strained.

item.title: World Briefing | Africa: Congo: Soldiers Retake Town Seized by Rebel Group
item.description: Soldiers in the Democratic Republic of Congo have taken back a town in eastern Congo occupied by a Ugandan rebel group, a government spokesman said.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing | Europe: Ukraine: Third Suspect Detained in Beating of Activist
item.description: Ukrainian authorities on Thursday increased the severity of potential charges in the case after initially deeming it a matter of “hooliganism.”
item.dc:creator: By DAVID M. HERSZENHORN

item.title: World Briefing | The Americas: Argentina: Carnivorous Fish Attack Bathers in a River
item.description: An attack by a school of carnivorous fish injured 70 people bathing in an Argentine river, including seven children, who lost parts of their fingers or toes, officials said.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing | Antarctica: Ice Traps Ship Carrying a Scientific Expedition Team
item.description: Three icebreakers are on their way to an area off the coast of Antarctica to help free a vessel carrying 74 people that is stranded in thick sheets of ice, officials said.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS
